content.question: Carbon dioxide equivalent ( <math alttext="C O 2 e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mi>e</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ) is used to compare contributions to climate change of various greenhouse gases. A study at a farm calculated the carbon dioxide equivalent for different production stages for beef and chicken production. Which of the following statements is best supported by the data in the graph?

choices.label: Producing food for beef and chicken emits a total of <math alttext="4.67 kilograms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.67</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="C O 2 e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mi>e</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> per <math alttext="kilograms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of edible meat, released during transport and processing of animal feed.

The carbon dioxide equivalent for farm energy use by chickens is the greatest source of emissions, because the <math alttext="24" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours of lighting that chickens require to grow uses a lot of electricity.
Raising beef contributes more to greenhouse gases than raising chickens does, primarily as a result of fermentation in cows’ digestive tracts, which releases methane gas.
Chicken manure does not emit any greenhouse gases, because chickens have unique symbiotic bacteria in their digestive systems.

content.answer: Raising beef contributes more to greenhouse gases than raising chickens does, primarily as a result of fermentation in cows’ digestive tracts, which releases methane gas.
